title: Critical Approaches in Literary Studies
requirements: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
description: The course aims at providing the students with an orientation of critical and interpretive approaches required of graduate studies in literature in a cross-cultural context. Various literary and critical paradigms from Western and Chinese traditions will be reviewed with a discussion of the basic issues in interpretation theory and criticism. The course will also focus on the implications of recent orientations in social sciences and philosophy for literary studies. Students will be required to identify their own research interests and pursue text- based case studies on problems or topics in criticism and interpretive theory that are involved in the interdisciplinary studies of literature.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to:  • Understand key concepts of a range of critical approaches to the study of literature. • Debate the pros and cons of such approaches and begin to develop personal preferences and affinities to a critical school or schools. • Choose a suitable approach or experiment with different approaches in the reading of literary texts and be alert to the merits and demerits of their choice. • Articulate their observations and thoughts in discussions, presentations and papers. • Relate the study of literature and theory to broader issues in politics, knowledge production, and society.

title: Comparative Approaches in Literary Studies
requirements: For students in MPhil English (Literary Studies) or MA English (Literary Studies)
description: The course serves as an introduction to the advanced study of literature from comparative perspectives. With a view to enhancing their ability in identifying problems and topics for research, students will be familiarized, through team-work instruction, with the basic techniques and methods of bibliographical research and textual criticism. This will involve the use of specific primary texts. Emphasis will be put on giving the students an overview of historical as well as current research in the field. The concept of comparative literature will be investigated along with the various cultural as well as literary issues particularly involved in the studies of literature in the Chinese-Western context. Traditional areas of research, such as influence and reception, themes and motifs, genres and forms, and interrelations of literature and art, will be reviewed in the light of recent literary and cultural theories. In this course students will have to read major literary and critical texts with regard to the various perspectives on comparative literature.
outcome: This course will acquaint graduate students with a number of basic concepts of theoretical positions in literary criticism, enable them to approach literature from a variety of perspectives, equip them with practical knowledge of how literary scholars develop their interpretations, and lead them to greater understanding of the primary features, strategies and implications of the main currents in literary theory and criticism such as new criticism, reader-response criticism, structuralism, deconstruction, psychoanalytic criticism, feminism, Marxism, new historicism, and cultural studies.

title: Special Topic(s) in Genre Studies
requirements: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
description: Specific area(s) of investigation will be defined every year to cover one or more of the following aspects in the critical and comparative studies of literary genre: poetics, prosaics; dramatic theories; narrative theories; questions of form and structure; issues in theme and style; concepts of character and hero; problems of generic convention and institution; as well as other topics related to the study of particular genres or subgenres of poetry, drama and fiction. Emphasis will be put on the dialectic between theory and practice. Textual analysis will be treated in relation to the critical investigation of possible cultural and historical contexts. Subject to the approval of the Division Head, students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.
outcome: • To be able to critically assess what constitutes cultural knowledge and the potential and limits of social media in engaging with culture.  • To be familiar with key ideas in ethnographic and auto-ethnographic research. • To explore the social, cultural and urban spaces of Hong Kong and elsewhere. • To be familiar with a range of critical debates in the field of modern writing/visual technologies and digital humanities. • To understand writing, photography and social media as different aspects of textuality.

title: Special Topic(s) in Literary History
requirements: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
description: Specific area(s) of investigation will be defined every year to cover one or more of the following aspects in the critical and comparative studies of literary history: influence and reception; period and movement; literary ideas and intellectual history; historicism; neohistoricism; classicism; neo-classicism; romanticism; symbolism; realism; modernism; postmodernism; functions and theories of literary history; perspectives of historical criticism; concepts of literary tradition; concepts of literary system; literary history and literary reception; feminist perspectives; materialist perspectives; problems of textuality and intertextuality. The chosen area(s) of investigation will use texts from all three major genres of poetry, drama, and fiction. Subject to the approval of the Division Head, students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.

title: Special Topic(s) in Critical Studies
requirements: For students in MA English (Literary Studies) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
description: This course is designed to investigate areas of specialisation normally not covered under generic studies or literary history. It may involve any one of the following areas in the comparative and interdisciplinary studies of literature: thematology, textual criticism and reader response, aesthetics, Western critical theories and Chinese literary studies, problems in the histories of literary criticism; twentieth-century critical theories; literature and the other arts; literature and sociology; literature and philosophy; literature and history; literature and language; literature and culture. Subject to the approval of the Division Head, students are allowed to take the above course more than once and gain the units each time they pass the course. However, students cannot take courses with the same course code more than once in a single term.
outcome: Students are expected to • have a holistic picture of the gothic writing in the Romantic era;  • have a grasp on the contribution each of the studied writers has made to the gothic tradition;  • have an understanding of the critical debate about the Gothic in literary history;  • have an awareness of the origin and legacy of the gothic.

title: M.Phil. Guided Research
requirements: For students in MPhil English (Applied English Linguistics) or MPhil English (Literary Studies)
description: In this course, the supervisor will meet with the student on a regular basis to give advice on all matters related to the preparation of a thesis proposal.
outcome: 1. Demonstrated progress in research plan through regular contact with the supervisor. 2. Production of a research paper that leads to the writing of the dissertation.

title: Ph.D. Guided Research
requirements: For students in PhD English (Applied English Linguistics) or PhD English (Literary Studies)
description: 6 units (also 6 units for part-time students) per term for a minimum of 12 units in preparation for the qualifying examination to be taken no later than the fourth semester (or the sixth semester for part-time students). In this course, the supervisor will see the student on a regular bi-weekly basis and work out a plan of study with the student.
outcome: Initial phase of the writing of dissertation under the guidance of supervisor.

title: Ph.D. Thesis Research
requirements: For students in PhD English (Applied English Linguistics) or PhD English (Literary Studies); Prerequisite: ENGE8100
description: 6 units (also 6 units for part-time students) per term for a minimum of 12 units in preparation of the thesis for the final oral examination. In this course, the supervisor will see the student on a regular bi-weekly basis and advise the student on all matters related to thesis research. Continuing students will be required to register for ENGE8200 throughout their thesis preparation.
outcome: Continuation of writing of dissertation leading to its eventual completion under the guidance of supervisor.
